Baire category theorem, Lp spaces

Let L1=L1([0,1])L^1 = L^1\p{\br{0,1}}L1=L1([0,1]) be the space of integrable and L2=L2([0,1])L^2 = L^2\p{\br{0,1}}L2=L2([0,1]) be the space of square-integrable functions on [0,1]\br{0,1}[0,1]. Then L2⊆L1L^2 \subseteq L^1L2⊆L1. Show that L2L^2L2 is a meager subset of L1L^1L1, i.e., L2L^2L2 can be written as a countable union of sets in L1L^1L1 that are closed and have empty interior in L1L^1L1.
Solution.

For n∈Nn \in \Nn∈N, let

En={f∈L2∣∥f∥L2≤n}.E_n = \set{f \in L^2 \mid \norm{f}_{L^2} \leq n}.En​={f∈L2∣∥f∥L2​≤n}.

which is closed: suppose {fk}k⊆En\set{f_k}_k \subseteq E_n{fk​}k​⊆En​ converges to fff in L1L^1L1. Then there exists a subsequence {fkℓ}ℓ\set{f_{k_\ell}}_\ell{fkℓ​​}ℓ​ which converges almost everywhere to fff. By Fatou's lemma,

∫∣f∣2≤lim inf⁡ℓ→∞∫∣fkℓ∣2≤n2,\int \abs{f}^2 \leq \liminf_{\ell\to\infty} \int \abs{f_{k_\ell}}^2 \leq n^2,∫∣f∣2≤ℓ→∞liminf​∫∣fkℓ​​∣2≤n2,

so f∈Enf \in E_nf∈En​. Since L2⊆L1L^2 \subseteq L^1L2⊆L1, it also follows that

L2=⋃n=1∞En,L^2 = \bigcup_{n=1}^\infty E_n,L2=n=1⋃∞​En​,

so it remains to show that EnE_nEn​ is nowhere dense.

First, observe that if φ(x)=x−1/2\phi\p{x} = x^{-1/2}φ(x)=x−1/2, then ∥φ∥L1<∞\norm{\phi}_{L^1} < \infty∥φ∥L1​<∞ and ∥φ∥L2=∞\norm{\phi}_{L^2} = \infty∥φ∥L2​=∞, i.e., φ∈L1∖L2\phi \in L^1 \setminus L^2φ∈L1∖L2. Hence, given f∈L2f \in L^2f∈L2 and ε>0\epsilon > 0ε>0, we see that f−εφ∈L1∖L2f - \epsilon\phi \in L^1 \setminus L^2f−εφ∈L1∖L2, or else

εφ=f−(f−εφ)∈L2.\epsilon\phi = f - \p{f - \epsilon\phi} \in L^2.εφ=f−(f−εφ)∈L2.

Moreover,

∥f−(f−εφ)∥L1=ε∥φ∥L1,\norm{f - \p{f - \epsilon\phi}}_{L^1} = \epsilon \norm{\phi}_{L^1},∥f−(f−εφ)∥L1​=ε∥φ∥L1​,

i.e., any open neighborhood of f∈L2f \in L^2f∈L2 contains an element in L1∖L2L^1 \setminus L^2L1∖L2. Thus, EnE_nEn​ is nowhere dense for each nnn, so L2L^2L2 is meager.
